answer.para: Having said that, I think it is proper that the government does take the decision on this. The honourable member for Curtin will know that the government has established a very high powered committee, and ministerial responsibility for that is with the Minister for Finance and Administration and the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism. One of the terms of reference of that committee is to look at the taxation consequences and make recommendations to the government, which I will be very happy to receive. I thank the member for his question.

talk.start.para: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business. Minister, can you inform the House of the impact that the leaking of sensitive material from the investigation into the bankruptcy of Christopher Skase has had on small business and what that has done to the likelihood of those small businesses getting some of their money back?
—Order! Honourable members for the opposition will remain silent. Has the honourable member for Bowman finished her question?
—I have.

—I thank the member for Bowman for her question. There is no doubt that, in circumstances where a big business goes bust and the attempts to recover moneys from the residue of such a business are thwarted, the people who suffer are those many thousands of small businesses which simply do not have the legal resources to chase the Skases of this world. That is why those small business operators really are reliant on the `system'—that is, government and the appropriate agencies—taking the appropriate action to ensure that funds are recovered.

answer.para: In this particular case, a lot of small businesses were impacted and suffered as a result of the fraud and associated activities of Mr Skase. For example, one small business was owed $1,700 for catering services. That business eventually, presumably for a number of reasons, went bankrupt, but they were not helped by a system where the Skases of this world are not properly pursued with the full might of the law. Another business—a chauffer and hire car company—was owed $1,859. It is now in liquidation, no thanks to the failure of the previous government to chase Mr Skase. Then there is the secretarial service which was owed $1,733.40 and the gallery which was owed $5,465.

These are small amounts and, from the opposition's point of view, a small amount is nothing when it comes to looking after one of their mates. If one of their mates has been protecting Christopher Skase, they think their obligation is to protect that mate—in this case, Senator Bolkus—instead of standing up for the small business community that deserves a system which will see every effort undertaken to bring these people to book.

The Leader of the Opposition and the Deputy Leader of the Opposition have form on these issues. They are both pattern protectors. They were the defence legal team for Mal Colston when they were two new members and ministers back in the early 1980s. They were the two who buried the Colston affair. Now we find they are protecting Senator Bolkus. They are doing so by standing up in the House, as they did last week, and misleading the House about the facts and the circumstances. To show you how low these people will go: they were making allegations that the minister had the affidavit, when her office did not even have the affidavit. I can assure the Leader of the Opposition and his sidekick the Deputy Leader of the Opposition that the small business community is very angry at your failure to deal with Senator Bolkus, and they will continue to remind you of it.

talk.start.para: —It would be of interesting for members, and particularly the opposition, to listen to this. You know, in social policy terms, that it is far better for that money to be in the hands of the parents. That is why we did it. talk.start.para: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business. answer.para: This latest attempt by the MUA is nothing other than industrial thuggery of the sort we have long seen from this union. Sadly, it is supported by the silence of the Labor opposition who, when in government, were never able to actually address these issues. They oversaw the spending of $420 million and we still have the rorts and inefficiencies on the Australian waterfront that are costing Australians jobs, costing us export income and other opportunities. At Patrick's Newcastle there is an Enterprise Communications committee designed to improve company employee communications. The committee is supposed to meet during idle time.

The Bulletin goes on to say:
The rort has to do with the grandly titled Enterprise Communications Committee.
The Newcastle wharfies recently refused to attend the committee meeting unless they were paid an extra quarter day off and an $11.20 meal allowance.

There is no end to the rorts and the rip-offs on the Australian waterfront. Labor had 13 years to do something about it and failed to do so. talker.name: Kemp, Dr David, MP
Dr KEMP
talker.role: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service

talk.start.para: —I thank the member for Riverina for his question. What I would like to draw attention to is that we do in fact owe thanks to the member for Batman. As a result of his earlier question today and remarks that he has been reported as making in the media, we immediately know what the truth of any matter is: it is the opposite of what the member for Batman has said or implied.

answer.para: The most recent of the inaccuracies that the member for Batman has put about was what he implied in his first question about Allhands Hire. I have now had advice about the actual facts of the situation. The member for Batman claimed that Allhands Hire is for sale. The facts are that All Hands Hire—as we are informed by the company itself—is not for sale. The financial viability check was carried out, and the company demonstrated an operating profit and a satisfactory financial situation to pass that. The company has a contract for some 2,000 job matching places.

talk.start.para: —How much is the contract?

—Let me make the point—because the point is raised that people are being given contracts worth a lot of money—that one of the great advantages of the new system is that no-one gets any money unless they place an unemployed person in a job. The payment is made when they get unemployed people into jobs; that is what the new system is about. It is not like your system which handed out money hand over fist, whether or not the performance was granted.

answer.para: Let me make the point, to put the facts clearly on the record, that if a company which has a contract in the new Job Network decides to sell the business as a commercial consideration, the contract does not automatically transfer to the purchaser of that business. It would require the agreement of the Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, who would assess the new owner's viability before any agreement would be made.

In other words, exactly the same rigorous process of assessment would apply. The procedures apply to any company that wants to sell within the 19-month period of the contract. That is by no means the limit of the inaccuracies that we keep getting from the member for Batman. On 7 March, on Canberra radio news, he stated that over 400,000 Australians will no longer be entitled to a helping hand—to that free employment service that used to be part of Australia's endeavour to get our unemployed people back to work. That is absolutely wrong. He is trying to spread fear and anxiety amongst unemployed people. He has never cared about unemployed people. We know the contempt in which he holds them, and we know that the Labor Party has only ever used its policies for unemployed people to try to manipulate the statistics.

The Prime Minister read to the House the statement issued by Employment National which clearly put paid to that matter. Every unemployed person in Job Network gets access to greatly upgraded facilities through Centrelink. They get an expanded vacancy list and they get access to a free computer, faxes, photocopiers and telephones to contact employers. All the major providers in Job Net work have clearly indicated to us that they will take any unemployed person and seek to match the best person to the vacancy. Not only has Employment National said that, as the Prime Minister indicated, but Drake has also said, `If they come to us, we would consider taking them for that job, along with everyone else who was the best person for the job. I can give you that undertaking.' The Salvation Army and Mission Australia have given us precisely the same undertakings. The Labor Party will say in this matter anything it takes to get a cheap vote—whatever it takes. The government is putting in place an outstanding system to help unemployed people and the Labor Party should stop trying to spread disinformation, fear and anxiety amongst the people in this community who need help.

—I move:

speech.para: That this House:
(1) condemns the persecution of all religious minorities around the world;
(2) deplores the long lasting plight of the Christian minorities in Turkey involving discrimination against those minorities to freely practice their religion and culture; and
(3) requests the Government of Turkey, in the interests of secularism and respect for minorities to:
(a) make it easier for all Christian denominations to be recognised as official churches and to have clear legal rights with regard to property ownership;

(b) allow the opening of the Greek Orthodox and Armenian Apostolic seminaries which were forcibly closed in 1971 and permit other Christian denominations such as the Syrian Orthodox to have seminaries as well;
(c) abolish the special tax imposed on Christian institutions;
(d) preserve Christian monuments and cease the destruction or desecration of Christian churches, monasteries and other religious monuments;

(e) provide more protection for the Ecumenical Patriarchate of the Orthodox church in Istanbul and Armenian and Greek Christian churches in Turkey, against possible further attacks by Islamic extremists;
(f) return to the Armenian Protestant Church all property that was taken from it including money that the Armenians were forced to pay; and
(g) not interfere in the selection of church leaders or in the affairs of the Christian communities, in particular the operations of schools.

I wish to bring to the attention of this House the discrimination and persecution of Christian minorities in the Republic of Turkey. This continuous abrogation of the most basic human rights is an appalling indictment on the Turkish government—a government which is a signatory to the Universal Declaration of Human Rights and a member of the United Nations.

Turkey's breaches of international agreements to respect and protect minorities are brazen and without shame. Historically this is linked to the incomprehensible denial by the Turkish government that the genocide of 1.5 million Armenians in the early part of this century ever took place, despite compelling evidence to the contrary. Coupled with the killing and expulsion of 1.5 million Greeks, the Turkish government's track record on protecting basic human and civil rights is shameful and deplorable.

Despite being a secular state since 1920, the Turkish government has abandoned the welfare of non-Muslim minorities. Early this century, Turkey was home to 12 million Christians. Today, barely 100,000 Christians are left. It was estimated in 1992 that some 60,000 were Armenian Orthodox and about 3,500 were Greek Orthodox.

The honourable member for Barton (Mr McClelland), who in the spirit of bipartisanship will second this motion, has agreed to speak in detail on the plight of the Greek community in Turkey. I wish to concentrate on the continued harassment and humiliation of the Armenian community in Turkey. The Armenian community has settled in the rural and remote regions of Turkey. Their isolation from the world, and subsequently international scrutiny, has put them in a state of virtual servitude to their Turkish neighbours. At the turn of this century, some 2.5 million Armenians lived in their ancestral lands in eastern Turkey, where they established a rich and vibrant culture. This was annihilated in the horrific Armenian genocide of 1915-1922. Entire Armenian communities were transported to death camps in the Syrian desert. Many Armenians who were not executed in their homes and villages were forced to march to their deaths.

Armenian males were conscripted into the Ottoman army and placed in labour battalions, where they were literally worked to death. Women, children and the elderly were rounded up and subjected to horrific atrocities. Some were raped, some were massacred and some were forcibly converted to Islam. For those lucky to survive, most were deported from their ancestral homes and exiled. When the genocide ended, 1.5 million Armenians had been killed and thousands more had been displaced. Every successive Turkish government has denied that this genocide ever occurred. In Ankara, there is even a mausoleum honouring the man who had the dubious honour of coordinating this mass extermination and deportation. The killings and deportations may have stopped, but the harassment and discrimination continues unchecked to this day.

In the 1920s, in flagrant disregard of the terms of the 1923 Lausanne treaty to protect the rights of minorities, the Turkish government passed a series of laws specifically directed at the Armenian community. Those who had left their villages during World War I were forbidden to return and individuals were prevented from reclaiming property. Since the 1930s, literally hundreds of Armenian religious and cultural monuments in historic Armenian provinces in eastern Turkey have been destroyed, and the preservation of what remains as symbolic cultural artefacts prohibited.

Although permitted to own property, a law passed in 1942 introduced a one-off tax on capital. After assessing property held by Armenians at greatly inflated values, many were forced to sell businesses and other assets to pay the tax. For those who could not raise sufficient money, a concentration camp awaited where many became ill or died. Today, a five per cent control tax is imposed on all minority-owned property, even though the law was officially repealed in 1980. A 1970s regulation in effect forbids most non-Turkish institutions from owning property purchased after 1936. This has led to the further confiscation of churches and schools without compensation.

An Armenian child cannot attend an Armenian school unless the child has completed the previous year in an Armenian school. Discontinuing attendance results in exclusion, and the child must complete his or her education in a Turkish school. Only Armenian language classes can be given in Armenian, and all classroom inscriptions are in Turkish. Outspoken Armenians cannot become teachers or administrators in schools. Furthermore, an ethnically Turkish vice-principal is appointed to each school, and their consent is required by the Armenian principal for every suggested initiative.

In the late 1980s, Armenian churches were closed for reasons of safety by the same authorities who refused to approve building repair applications. The Armenian church was denied a seminary in which to train clergymen, and the Turkish authorities have interfered in the election of Armenian church leaders. In another insidious form of ethnic cleansing, in a village in Erzurum a former Armenian church is currently being converted into a mosque. Only last Friday, reports were sent from occupied northern Cyprus that the Turkish government was intending to convert a former Armenian church into a hotel.

Isolated acts of violence by individual Armenians and organisations outside Turkey in the 1970s and 1980s were seized on by the Turkish government to heighten anti-Armenian sentiment. A wave of hostility towards the Armenian community swept the country. Violent attacks on the Armenian Patriarchate, churches and schools became commonplace.

The acts of intimidation perpetuated by the Turkish government have a clear purpose—to destabilise the core institutions of the Armenian and other Christian minorities. These communities are unsettled by continual attempts to undermine the ability of churches and schools to function properly. An air of uneasiness and disquiet has descended on these people. These constraints on their fundamental human rights have taken their toll on community and family life. And while 1.5 million Armenians can never be brought back, the international community has an obligation and a duty to protect Christian minorities living in Turkey and to guard against the risk that such atrocities may occur again.

Mr Deputy Speaker, today in the gallery we are joined by a large number of representatives from the Armenian community in my electorate and from the Greek community all around Australia. I would like to welcome them here today because they, too, represent part of the protest at what the Turkish government is doing. As the representative in this House of the largest Armenian community in Australia, I can confirm the determination of this community to continue to place an international spotlight on the Turkish violations of human rights. We in the House of Representatives today join with others around the world, including the United States Commission on Security and Cooperation in Europe, in condemning the ongoing discrimination and harassment of Christian minorities in Turkey.

The Armenian diaspora scattered around the world is living testament to the failure of the Ottoman Empire to exterminate the Armenian people. I urge my colleagues to consider the obligations we owe to communities who are suffering as the Armenians and the Greeks in Turkey are suffering and join with me in vociferously supporting this motion.

talk.start.para: —Is the motion seconded?

—I second the motion, with honour. I join with the member for North Sydney (Mr Hockey) in welcoming members of the Armenian and Greek communities to this House. It is an important matter, not only for their communities but also, as I frame my debate, for the entire world. Indeed, I should add that not only were there literally in excess of 1½ million Armenians murdered in the early part of this century, but among them were some 400,000 Greeks who were lost in that genocide. But these are things that the Turkish government must account for regarding past conduct. What we are looking at today is what they should be doing in the present day and age.

speech.para: After the Second World War, the international community realised that human rights extended beyond national boundaries. Indeed, the international community realised that there could not be world peace unless there was respect for fundamental human rights. So the nations which formed the United Nations gave attention, very early in the life of the United Nations, to very important treaties regarding fundamental human rights. We have the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights and, more recently, the European Convention on Human Rights. There are many others that affect this area but, univer sally, they focus on the rights of minorities. Those rights include the freedom of religion and the freedom to respect and uphold cultural identity.

In terms of Greeks residing in Turkey, these were not the first treaties to apply. In 1923 the Treaty of Lausanne guaranteed a number of fundamental rights. Regrettably there is a significant creditability gap, however, between those signed and ratified treaties and the conduct that is displayed. Very recently, the Turkish Prime Minister is on record as saying that he is determined to end human rights abuses in Turkey. Motions such as this—and they are commonplace around the world—put him on notice that, increasingly, the international community is becoming impatient with that creditability gap between Turkey's pen and its actions in its own country.

The motion raises a number of issues to which I will speak briefly. The Turkish government fails to recognise certain Christian denominations and, as a consequence, those denominations are unable to hold real property. Indeed, the ownership by churches which do hold real property is frequently the subject of ambiguity. Buildings are often arbitrarily confiscated without any compensation being paid. There is clearly a need for the Turkish government to recognise all Christian denominations and guarantee them the right to hold property.

In 1971, as with the Armenians, the Turkish government closed the Halki Patriarchal School of Theology, which had existed since 1844. Because Turkish rule requires that the Patriarch and other clergy of the Greek Orthodox Church must be citizens of Turkey, that is a very serious problem indeed for the patriarchate. Because there is no long-term training facility for the clergy, there are no clergy from whom the patriarchate can draw. The hidden game of that strategy of cutting out the training base is designed to cause the extinction of the Greek Orthodox faith in Turkey. This motion justifiably calls for a reopening of those apostolic seminaries that were forcibly closed in 1971.

The member for North Sydney spoke of the special tax of about five per cent on Christian institutions, which tax is not justified in any context other than that they are Christian institutions. Over the years, not paying that tax has resulted in countless abuses. Also, it has resulted in the confiscation of the property of those institutions that have been unable to meet the fee in a context where, as a result of intimidation and pressure, the populations of those churches are declining, thus making the burden of the taxation even more oppressive. The motion calls for the repeal of those taxes.

Recent history has demonstrated at least apathy to, at worst positive encouragement of, the destruction and desecration of some Christian churches and monasteries and other religious monuments. In respect of the Greek Orthodox faith, there have been statues desecrated, and even cemeteries, to the distress of relatives, have been desecrated. While it may appear perhaps more trivial, the facts of the matter are that the authorities have used church buildings from the Greek Orthodox faith and, I have no doubt, other Christian faiths for quite inappropriate ceremonies within those hallowed buildings. That has been very much an affront to the those of the Greek Orthodox faith.

The other way that the government is causing a decline in the significance of the religious institutions is to deliberately restrict the preservation of these buildings. They do this under the guise of a preservation order just as we have in many cities around Australia for the preservation of historical buildings of significance. But these preservation orders are framed in such a way that basic repairs and renovations to uphold and maintain the buildings have been prevented. Hence, decay is rapidly setting in. The motion calls for steps to preserve and maintain Christian monuments and buildings.

The Turkish government has over the years boasted that the presence of the ecumenical patriarchate of the Orthodox church in Istanbul is an example of its racial and religious tolerance. But the facts of the matter are that it has failed to give that patriarchate its proper respect and indeed it has failed to give appropriate and proper protection. There have been riots in the vicinity of the patriarchate that have infringed on the property. Indeed, there was an attempt in 1993 to bomb the patriarchate. While those attempts were defused, it is quite clear that sufficient protection is not being given in a context where the Turkish government, through its propaganda, is evoking sentiments against the Greek Orthodox faith. The motion appropriately calls for proper protection for those Christian institutions.

There are also instances, which Mr Hockey, the member for North Sydney, has referred to, where property and money have been confiscated. It is often done under more clever guises—for instance, saying that a road widening plan is going through an area and therefore properties are being confiscated on that false premise. Indeed, history has shown that the premise has been false because a road widening has not occurred. Again, that is another method of acquisition.

The government itself has had a history of censoring and restricting proper administration. Again, the member for North Sydney spoke of arrangements in public schools whereby there is a dual principal arrangement so that one is appointed by the Turkish government and the books of the students are significantly censored, and whereby there is restriction on the teaching of Greek history and indeed the Greek language. That censorship applies to any newspapers espousing the Greek Orthodox faith. Many Australians would be quite astounded to know that even the candidates for the patriarchate have to be vetted by the Turkish government.

This is a situation which is totally unsatisfactory in the modern world when we are two years away from the 21st century. The Turkish government is on notice. It cannot hope to have full admission to the international community until it gets its house in order in terms of these human rights abuses.

talk.start.para: —Today I rise to speak about the ongoing persecution of Christian minorities in Turkey. I would like to congratulate the member for North Sydney (Mr Hockey) on this motion. It is an important and timely issue, and I have received several letters of support for its contents from many Greek and Armenian people in Australia. I would also like to acknowledge representatives from the Greek and Armenian communities in Australia who are in the gallery. This is a very extended motion and unfortunately in the few minutes I have to speak to it I will speak only on (1) and (2), but I do support the whole motion.

speech.para: Too often we take for granted the freedoms we enjoy in Australia. We go about our daily lives without interference from our government. We freely choose our schools that our children attend. We practise religion freely. We own property and are promoted on the basis of our ability, regardless of our ethnic background or religious beliefs. For those of the Christian faith in Turkey, this is not the case. Turkish government interference with Christian communities is not new. It has been going on for centuries.

Mr Deputy Speaker Nehl, you may be aware that I am of Greek origin. I am a second generation Australian. But during the course of my early boyhood days when growing up I was always advised of and schooled in the atrocities caused by the Turks on Greeks in Turkey. In fact, most of the Australian Greeks who came in the early 1900s had to change their names in order to get travel documents to move through Asia Minor or either come to Australia, or go to America, England or wherever they wanted to go. For example, they abbreviated their names to get passports.

When the island of Kastelorizo, where my forebears came from, was under Turkish control the children had to be schooled in secrecy in a monastery. In the monastery on top of the mountain on Kastelorizo there was a little passageway no bigger than the human body through which they were able to go into a very large cavern where they were schooled in the Greek religion and our culture.

Interference with the Christian community by the Turkish government is not new. The execution of nearly two million Armenian and Greek christians between 1914 and 1922 brought home the extent to which the government would go to create `Turkey for Turks'. In 1974 the invasion of Cyprus by the Turks, taking away the rights of those Cypriot Greeks to practise their culture and their religion, was certainly something condemned by the United Nations at the time. Unfortunately, some 21 years later, that same situation exists—a disgrace that the Turkish community have obviously supported.

Christians in Turkey now constitute only about 0.2 per cent of the population. Sadly, as the numbers of Christians in Turkey fall, it becomes easy for the government to restrict their lives. There are many contemporary examples of this restriction. In 1970 the ministry of education prohibited prayers in minority schools. In 1984 a law was introduced that prohibited the establishment of schools for the teaching of religion. The time allotted to religious education is also tightly controlled. I am told that Christians are assigned a Turkish Muslim principal for every Christian one as only Turkish Muslims, not Christians, can be recognised as government officials.

The plight of Turkish Christians has often been overlooked as the world focuses on the persecution of the Turkish Kurds, who are fighting for a sovereign nation in the south west of the country. Turkey's Christians want to live in peace within the borders of Turkey. They do not ask for the overthrow of the Turkish government. They do not seek political sovereignty. All they ask for is the freedom to practise their religion in safety. This freedom is guaranteed by the Treaty of Lausanne signed in 1923, a treaty constantly ignored by the Turkish government.

The Commission on Security and Cooperation in Europe wrote to the Turkish Prime Minister, Mesut Yilmaz, on 24 February 1998 after a delegation visited Turkey, Greece and Cyprus to examine human rights in the region. The commission expressed concern over the continuing closure of the Halki seminary as well as, and I quote from their letter:

. . . the situation of other minority religions or beliefs, including Armenian and Syrian Orthodox believers, as well as Roman Catholics, Armenian, Chaldean Greek and Syrian Catholics, and Protestants who face various forms of discrimination and harassment.
I join with the international community in calling for the protection of Christian church es and institutions in Turkey. I commend the motion to the House.

talk.start.para: —The motion that the House is debating this afternoon is an important motion because it says something about our country as well as the country we are talking about, Turkey. The motion essentially asks us to condemn the persecution of all religious minorities around the world and particularly the effects that the Turkish government are causing to Christian minorities in Turkey. Many people have come to this country from Turkey and from countries around it and are able, in this country, to share with people from all over the world their religious and political freedoms. In Turkey, that is not so.

speech.para: The Turkish government is, at this stage, actively working against Christians in a financial way and earlier this century did it in a most inhumane and murderous way in that two million people were marched off and killed and whole communities were uprooted. Communities that had been living around the Bosphorus and the Black Sea for hundreds and hundreds of years were just obliterated. A whole culture was obliterated, and this was done by the Turkish government.

Turkey, as my colleague the member for the Northern Territory (Mr Dondas) said, has forgotten nothing and learnt nothing. In 1974, as he said, they invaded the island of Cyprus and started to do the same thing—moved people out, killed people and desecrated churches. There are still icons being sold on the international market which have been plundered from churches in northern Cyprus. Churches in northern Cyprus have been turned into barracks and have been turned into living quarters.

What the Turkish government did in Turkey they are now doing in northern Cyprus, and this is a country that expects to become part of the European Union shortly. Turkey is a member of NATO. Turkey is a country that puts its public face forward as a Western liberal democracy but beneath that public face there is a murderous anti-social, anti-Christian attitude. One does not expect that Turkey should become pro-Christian; one just expects that Christians in Turkey should have the same rights as people of the Islamic faith have in other Western countries.

What we are asking for is that people have the same rights—that Christians in Turkey should have the same rights that Turkish people have here in Australia. That is not asking much. I think, as I am sure my colleagues do, that this parliament should have a point of view on that, that the Australian people, through their representatives here, should say that. While it is not normal that we have a vote on matters of private members business, I think today on this matter we should. So that we can do that, I move:
That the question be now put.

talk.start.para: —There being more than one voice calling for a division, under standing order 193 the division is deferred until the conclusion of the grievance debate.
—I move:

speech.para: That this House:

(1) expresses its absolute disgust at the worsening industrial relations climate throughout Australia as a number of foreign owned companies and their maverick Australian subsidiaries seek to use the Howard Government's workplace relations legislation to confront, intimidate and harass Australian workers and their spouses and children and to threaten the viability, stability and peace of Australian communities;

(2) deplores the gross and unconscionable behaviour of the American owned Atlantic Richfield Company for sacking all of the workers at its Gordonstone mine in Queensland with the intention of re-opening the mine with scab labour on individual contracts;

(3) calls on Rio Tinto to halt its continuing provocation against its employees at Hunter Valley No. 1 Mine and their spouses and children and seek to approach industrial relations in a more civilised and co-operative way;

(4) urges all respectable and responsible Australian firms to reject the behaviour of the mavericks and renegades whose offensive assaults on decency in the industrial relations system will cost Australian industry and the general community dearly;

(5) encourages all Federal and State industrial tribunals to utilise the laws, conventions and facilities available to them to demand that employers enter into genuine negotiations with unions and seek to achieve honourable settlements, arbitrated if necessary;
(6) demands that the Howard Government act immediately and decisively to halt the frightening trend towards the intrusion of potential violence in our approach to industrial relations;
(7) expresses its unqualified support for the courageous workers and their families who have been forced to put themselves in the front line of sacrifice to protect the rights of all workers; and

(8) calls on all Australians who value and respect our great traditions of fair play, mateship, collective action and civilised relationships to reject the intrusion of un-Australian behaviour into Australia's industrial relations system.

Let me say at the outset that I am proud to move this motion. I am not pleased though that the motion needs to be moved. I also want to take this early opportunity to thank so many of my colleagues who have sought the opportunity to be included in this debate so that they could support it. I refer particularly to the member for Hunter (Mr Fitzgibbon), within whose electorate Hunter Valley No. 1 colliery is located. He and I joined those striking coalminers at Hunter Valley No. 1 at the picket line. He has indicated his support for them, for their objectives, and for their union and in no way has ever abandoned them.

I notice that the two government members who are to speak on this motion are the member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) and the member for Paterson (Mr Bob Baldwin). Let me say that the member for Paterson has constituents employed at Hunter Valley No. 1. I hope that neither he nor the member for O'Connor take the opportunity to malign, misrepresent or ridicule those coalminers at Hunter Valley No. 1. I hope as well that the member for Paterson does not betray them. But I will live in hope.

There is no more important question, to my mind, that can come before the parliament. As I say, I have been proud to move this particular motion. I am delighted that the member for Throsby (Mr Hollis) will be speaking in support of it as well. Every one of the important issues that could come before this parliament involves questions of decency, equity, fair play, proper standards, proper processes and just outcomes.

Good governments are supposed to act as moderating and civilising influences to equalise the balance between otherwise unequal members of the community, to redress injustice, to provide safety nets, to respect the dignity of individuals and to enact laws which are socially responsible and morally defensible. This government fails by any measure on all of those counts.

There are numerous examples of ways in which this government has been supporting the operation of rogue multinational corporations in Australia which have taken the opportunity to attack traditional industrial relations processes, to attack unionists and to attack unions. We have had some local examples. For example, the present government defended the Tweed Valley Fruit Processors when they sought the opportunity for employees to trade off their sick leave.

At Weipa, this coalition government supported CRA, which, of course, is another name for Rio Tinto, which discriminated between employees doing the same work. They wanted to pay non-union labour, contract labour, a greater amount for doing the same work as unionists until the Industrial Relations Commission indicated that that was illegal and was not allowed. But this coalition government and its spokesman, the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business (Mr Reith), supported it.

At the port of Cairns, we had the government encouraging Freeport to use scab labour to load and unload its ships. Last year, the government was forced to admit that it was involved with about 20 serving army personnel being trained in Dubai to act as strike breakers and to act as non-union scabs on the Australian waterfront. We have the present provocations involved at Webb Dock with Patrick stevedores and the National Farmers Federation.

It was just October last year when the foreign owned Atlantic Richfield Company, known as Arco, sacked its entire work force at the Gordonstone Colliery in Queensland to take them back on as non-union scab labour on individual contracts. We know now that Arco at the Gordonstone mine in Queensland employed 50 armed security guards. Those guards patrolled the streets. They tailed the cars of unionists. They took photographs of families. They frightened the wives and kids of unionists. Workers were sacked by that company and then evicted from their homes. All that type of thing is becoming commonplace.

Rio Tinto, of course, is a foreign company, a transnational, which seeks to destroy the protection of workers provided by trade unions. It is doing this wherever it operates right around the world. It is not only supported by this government but also nurtured, encouraged and assisted by this government. It has used threats and intimidation. It has used misrepresentation. It has used abuse and provocation against its own employees. Rio Tinto is a rogue corporation in Australia with a thug mentality.

At Hunter Valley No. 1 there has been an avalanche of disgraceful acts committed against coalminers, their wives and their children, at the behest of the owner, Rio Tinto. Only seven of 430 employees accepted individual contracts in the face of provocation, intimidation, bribes, insults, threats, betrayal, whispering campaigns and court action. The union members have stood firm and their wives and children have stood with them and stood by them.

Allan Davies, the mine manager, kept issuing newsletters which were clearly designed to inflame and provoke the union members. They contained distortions and lies. He was spoiling to provoke the union into acting illegally, but the union kept its cool. In August last year, the Industrial Relations Commission recommended that changes to work practices be deferred until a negotiation period was completed. The mine management ignored it. In November, the IRC also recommended that no changes be made to work rosters. Again, the mine management ignored it. The mine management also threatened to sack half the work force from Hunter Valley No. 1 and its sister mine at Mount Thorley. It implied that workers on individual contracts would keep their jobs.

Rio Tinto instructed management at Hunter Valley No. 1 not to offer work or orders to 12 Newcastle and Hunter Valley firms which it claimed did not support it during the disputes. The memo said in part:
In all cases, there are a number of alternative suppliers already approved for use at Hunter Valley. Wherever possible, please do not use the below mentioned suppliers.

Then it went on to list a dozen of them. As I said, women and children have been stalked by the agents of these companies. They have been followed in motor vehicles. Cars have gone past their homes photographing the wives and the kids. The kids have been frightened by it, and this is what is being supported by this government and by this minister. It is an absolute disgrace. It is against all the principles of decency and all the traditions of trade union processes that exist in Australia, and this government seeks the kudos for the sorts of things that it has been guilty of.

Because of the potential damage to the New South Wales economy by that continuing dispute, the New South Wales Premier asked that the matter be arbitrated by the Industrial Relations Commission. Alan Boulton indicated that he was prepared to arbitrate, but what did the minister for industrial relations in this national coalition government say? He said, `Let them fight it out. There will be no arbitration. Let them fight it out. Let them go for the throat.' That has not existed since the system of arbitration and conciliation was introduced at the beginning of this century, and that is what Mr Reith has sought to put into place.

Rio Tinto has sought to bankrupt its workers both financially and emotionally, and it did so with the support of this government and this minister. The Newcastle Morning Herald, for example, in connection with that matter, said in an editorial on 2 October last year:
It is all very well for politicians who are paid from the public purse to sit back and let powerful company and union forces slug it out brutally in a winner-takes-all encounter.

That might satisfy a particular political agenda but it ignores the welfare of people caught in the middle of a dispute—and surely a key role of government is to look after the welfare of the nation and its communities?
Yes, indeed. That responsibility should be honoured and pursued by governments, not ignored by them.

Before anyone rushes to judgment on the side of the anti-union provocateurs and strike breakers, let them visit the United Mine Workers union office in Aberdare Road, Cessnock, and examine the 1,532 names of men and boys killed in the coal mines of the Hunter Valley; and, to those, we can add at least the names of the four miners who drowned in the Gretley mine in November 1996. It is left to the unions, like the CFMEU and the MUA, and the union leaders, like John Maitland and John Coombs, to protect unionists and to continue the traditions of unionism. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Is the motion seconded?
—I have great pleasure in seconding the motion and reserve my right to speak.
—The motion that we are debating at this time, which was moved by the member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown), commences with the words:

speech.para: That this House:
(1) expresses its absolute disgust at the worsening industrial relations climate throughout Australia—

For whom? For the 140,000 Australians who have got a job in recent times? For the extra five per cent of people who can now apply for a job because, the ANZ Bank tells us, job advertisements have grown by that much? Is that an industrial relations problem for them? Isn't it a fact that, because people are becoming more employable and do not have to have a ticket to get a job, there are a lot of people starting to get employment and they think the industrial relations system is pretty good?

I will tell you who has got a little worried, firstly, about their job prospects and, secondly, about their power and influence. The member for Charlton's speech was not about protecting workers and their children; it was about protecting the rights of union bureau crats. Isn't it interesting that last week we had a few people from the MUA come and visit? They are a pretty struggling lot! One bloke had two Montblanc pens in his pocket. I have got one, but I doubt I could afford the second one. It must be a pretty good job. You wonder why they are fighting by the death to keep it.

Let us face it: this speech is not about people getting jobs or people having good employment conditions. All of those can be clearly specified in a workplace agreement. It is about keeping people in work and creating an opportunity in Australia for those who have not got a job to get one.

I reminded the MUA people the other day of the circumstances that we all confront today in Australia. Australians' point of view about living standards is that we should have Australian wages and we should have Australian working conditions—and I support that—but the other side of the equation is that they believe we should have Chinese prices at K-Mart. The Chinese in their country, the Japanese in theirs and the Europeans in theirs have exactly the same attitude. They are not worried about Hunter Valley No. 1 mine. They are not worried about one of these other places. They have three questions when they decide whether people will stay in employment in Australia. They want to know how good, how soon and how much.

If the proprietors of a particular coalmine—and please remember that Rio Tinto, which we have now converted to this monstrous international organisation, is a partner with CRA, a genuine, dinki-di Aussie company, and I think the chief executive, admittedly now residing in London, is an Aussie, too—cannot answer those questions, the simple fact is that the buyers go somewhere else. There is no law in Australia that demands that you have to go broke.

I deal with a lot of working people and, in all my life, I have probably had more contact than a lot of people who occupy the back benches over there. I served beer for 30 years in my own pub and, if you think that is not a way to get contact with the working people, then think again.

talk.start.para: —That's where you used to wield the iron bar.

—Yes, that was there, too, and I make no apologies at all for that. But the reality is that those people—particularly in the north-west, when the roads were too rough for the union blokes to come up and collect their dues—usually seemed to get pretty good arrangements with their bosses, and most of them were for amounts of money that were well and truly above what they might have got under an award.

speech.para: I heard the member for Charlton bemoaning the fact that the people at Rio Tinto and the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business (Mr Reith) did not want arbitration, even when Premier Carr wanted it. Gosh, I have a good recollection of history and I would like 50c—not even a dollar—for every time the Industrial Relations Commission, or whatever its various names have been, arbitrated a dispute somewhere around Australia and the union bureaucrats said to the commission, `Stick it up your nose. We're staying on strike.' They used to take no notice whatsoever of what the Industrial Relations Commission said. Now, because there are a few changes to the rules and the goalposts have been squeezed a little closer together, suddenly they want arbitration.

The real problem is getting Australia right. We have got to protect our good living standards and we have got to take some quantum leaps. We know what wages are in parts of the world, but they are not nearly as cheap as we think they are simply because, frequently, the productivity of the people getting a pittance is extremely low. They are not nearly as competitive as we might think.

In that context, I asked the seamen present with the MUA the other day if they could consider a situation where they could man ships at less expense but maintain their wages, or where ships had family accommodation on board so they could go to sea for longer periods but had their family on board and probably their partner employed on board. It was interesting because they started to say, `What about our kids' education?' That is a relevant question, but I pointed out that, where I was in the north-west of Western Australia, people had to find out in gaining employment how to fix that, so they took extension—

talk.start.para: —What about the cost?

—It might be a lot cheaper. That is a good question, but nobody has ever thought of it. You are exactly the same. You want to be in government one day, but the first time someone stands up and says, `Is there a better way to make Australian shipping competitive so twice as many seamen have a job?' you start finding reasons that it will not work.

speech.para: That is silly, because it is all a cost-benefit analysis. You start saying there is this problem and that problem. One bloke asked, `Take my kids to sea?' I said, `I read all the time about little kids going around the world in someone's yacht.' I would not recommend it, but the realities are that there are options. I give you an example and it might be a poor one—

talk.start.para: —Have you been on a ship lately?

—There you go. Don't try to be progressive, don't try to lift Australia into a position where we would be the great seafaring nation we should be; just put up the shutters and complain about the intimidation of poor old trade unionists. There is not one trade union bureaucrat who is not on as good a salary as we are getting here.
—That's rubbish.
—Don't tell me about it.
—My salary doubled to come into this joint. That's absolute lies.
—You mustn't have been very highly regarded amongst your colleagues. You probably got what they reckoned you were worth. Let me tell you about it in terms of Webb Dock.
—I was the lowest paid in my organisation on 39 grand a year. That's absolute lies.

—Come on, don't be silly. If you cannot cop a bit of shot in this, you're a kid—and that's not a bad description either. But the realities are that when we get to this point of efficiency we get told that this is all intimidation. We actually have a stevedoring company that wants to rent a bit of its available space to somebody else, and that is a conspiracy! How stupid can you get! Every day of the week someone rents something to somebody else. In small business, people take over someone else's business and they say, `I'm sorry, I don't need any of your staff. Take them with you.' We do not have pickets—we do not have that.

speech.para: The one surviving bastion of trade union bureaucracy, the MUA, is under threat. That is what you are standing up here arguing about—not the rights of workers. They are getting jobs. The more efficient our country is, the more jobs we will have and the more we will have at the wages that people get today. But, if we do not match the efficiency and the productivity per hour of our competitors, do not think anybody else in the world is sympathetic to our needs. They want to buy their own products for a start, and they will buy in the cheapest and most efficient market.

Let me close on this point about the waterfront: the big cost is not only in moving containers but in shipping freight. We are rated as a war zone, because half the competitive shipping companies of the world refuse to come to Australia. I have had actual examples put to me of where people lost contracts in that fashion. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I rise in total support for the motion moved by my colleague the honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown). We on this side have never been fooled by the flowery words which surround the introduction of this government's workplace relations legislation. This legislation has never been about improving productivity, or establishing positive working relationships between the boss and the worker at the workplace, or ensuring the delivery of the rock solid guarantee that no worker would be worse off or lose any take home pay. For the Prime Minister (Mr Howard), the world of industrial relations—an obsession of decades—has always been about attacking trade unions, their membership, their wages and conditions of employment.

speech.para: This legislation has substantially shifted the balance of the employment relationship in only one direction—in favour of the bosses. The government's industrial relations agenda is about protecting bosses who want to mug the workers. Industrial relations in Australia are beginning to sink into a state of civil war. We have confrontation, division, intimidation, harassment—and all supported, encouraged, aided and abetted by the Prime Minister, the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business (Mr Reith) and every member who sits on the government side.

Throughout Australia, conservative governments have introduced legislation which allows ordinary workers to be mugged by employers because of the diminished role of awards and independent conciliation and arbitration, collective bargaining rights and court sanctioned prosecution to intimidate unionists from taking legitimate industrial action. The honourable member for Charlton has already mentioned the disputes in the Hunter Valley and Gordonstone. We can also add the disputes in Melbourne at Webb and East Swanson Docks to indicate this slide into chaos.

The Illawarra has not escaped the dogma of confrontation, now a dominant feature of a boss's industrial relations strategy. On Friday, 30 January, workers at the New South Wales Grain Corporation's Pivot facility at Port Kembla finished their shifts as they had done over the last two years. I wish the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) was in here to listen to this. On Monday, 1 February they arrived at work, as we all do, but in their case they discovered that they had been replaced by other workers. There was no warning, no notice provided and in the end they had no jobs—they were sacked.

It is interesting to note the company which provided the replacement workers. It is none other than the infamous Drake International, which has been granted an enormous slice of the employment services market by this government. No wonder those on that other side support them.

Over the last 12 months, the Pivot workers and their union, the AWU, have been involved in negotiations to establish an enterprise bargaining agreement at the Pivot site. There was nothing outrageous in their de mands—just basic working conditions: a 38-hour week, overtime payments after eight hours work and continuity of employment.

The Pivot workers did not go on strike during the negotiations, the AWU did not impose bans and the company had no complaint about the workers or their performance. But they were all sacked on 1 February, locked out of their jobs and replaced by scabs—scabs!—supplied by Drake International. The Grain Corporation has defended its action by saying that the four workers it had employed were only casuals and that negotiations to establish an enterprise agreement were taking up too much of the management's time.

Can you believe this? Workers were sacked because management at Pivot—and this is the opposition's industrial relations policy—could not find the time to negotiate an agreement which is encouraged by this legislation. If anyone deserves sacking, it is the incompetent Pivot management. Since 1 February, workers, their families, their union and their supporters, including me, have established a peaceful protest line outside the Pivot gate—and this is now the sixth week. These four sacked workers joined the workers at the Hunter Valley, Gordonstone and the docks in the front line to protect the rights of all workers which the Howard government is prepared to see destroyed.

Last week, I was informed that a woman admitting to being an employee of the Office of the Employment Advocate had been visiting the protest vigil daily and undertaking video and other surveillance activities there. I have put a question on notice to the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business about the matter and I look forward to his response. Industrial relations in this country is turning ugly—and all to fulfil the Howard government's manic hatred of the trade union movement. But the trade union movement has seen such attacks before, as have workers, and the Labor movement will continue to struggle and fight, as it always has, to protect the rights of workers against conservative governments and the bosses they harbour and protect. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Concerning the opening comments by the honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown) about who was speaking here, I am just sad that they did not have enough trust or support to put the member for Hunter (Mr Fitzgibbon), who has Rio Tinto in his electorate, up to speak on this motion. I can only presume that the member for Charlton is launching his own personal crusade and subtle dig in the ribs, as an exiting MP, to Cheryl Kernot, the former senator, who obviously opposes him outright on this very issue. I remind this House that it was Cheryl Kernot who, after all the details of the Workplace Relations Act were explained, voted 100 per cent in support of the legislation. Indeed, I remind members opposite, as perhaps they rub shoulders with Cheryl Kernot at the next Labor Party meeting, that it was discussed and amended to suit her. So we know we have her support.

speech.para: I suppose the one thing that we will see, now that Cheryl has gone over to the opposition side, is that she will convert, as she is the shadow minister for baby boomers, all of those people over there—all union officials and not a small business person amongst them—and tell them what it is like to be in business and that they should support this legislation, which brings about the right between unions and the workplace to come to some sort of agreement without government interference.

Last week, I had a phone call in my office from a miner who thought that the government was closing down a coal mine. I said, `Why do you think we are closing down a coal mine?' He said that he had heard on the radio that the government was closing down a coal mine. I said, `That's not quite so.' He said quite clearly something which sticks in my mind, that is, `All I want, as a worker in a coal mine, is for the government to stay out of an issue between the union and the company. It's about time they were both grown up and mature enough to see what is in the best interests of all Australians and their own individual needs and bring about a resolution on that basis.' As I said, it was, after all, Cheryl Kernot, as the then senator and Leader of the Democrats, who saw the absolute logic behind an overhaul of Australia's industrial relations system as the central plank to our government's goal of restoring and sustaining a strong, growing, competitive economy—growth that is delivering net benefits to all of the people of the Hunter.

This is illustrated by the facts from the Hunter Valley Research Foundation—that, in the year ending December 1997, the Hunter experienced a rate of jobs growth of five per cent, some 12 times the state average. Its business indicator survey pointed to a 10 per cent growth in Hunter business activity for the final quarter of 1997. As I said, it was Cheryl Kernot, now the Labor candidate for Dickson and self-appointed shadow minister for baby boomers, who correctly recognised that the Workplace Relations Act was, at the end of the day, about industrial evolution, not about a revolution of the kind that the honourable member for Charlton would have us believe. I was disappointed to hear the honourable member for Charlton claim that Minister Reith had said, `Let them rip each other's throats out.'

talk.start.para: —He did.
—He did.

—Mr Reith would not say that. What he would say is, `Let them work it out.' The problem is that those opposite come from a background of industrial violence, such as we saw on Webb Dock, where a rock was thrown through the window of a bus transporting people rightfully entering a workplace, and such as we saw here—union controlled and excited by members opposite—at the front doors of Parliament House, the house of democracy.

speech.para: The Workplace Relations Act—the new era of industrial evolution that has come to this grand piece of legislation—is evolution for small business, evolution that echoes freedom of association, evolution that outlaws closed shops and prohibits discrimination on the basis of membership or non-membership of a union, evolution that kills off secondary boycotts, evolution that provides a balanced system by putting the responsibility for wages and conditions, enshrined where practical in law, where they belong—in the hands of the employees and the employers. It is about time they both sat down to work it out and make a considered, responsible decision. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I am delighted to rise in support of the motion by the member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown), a motion which I happened to second. The member for Paterson (Mr Bob Baldwin) has made reference to the fact that I was not one of the earlier speakers. But, of course, there are two aspects to this motion, one which relates to coal mining and one which relates to those under attack on the nation's wharves. It is more than appropriate that the mover of the motion, the member for Charlton, be given an opportunity to talk about the mines and the member for Throsby (Mr Hollis), in particular, be given an opportunity to talk about what is happening to the people he represents.

speech.para: What amazes me is the approach and the response of the member for Paterson. Unfortunately, I do not have the figures with me. I do not know how many of those of Hunter Valley No. 1 mine reside in the Paterson electorate, but I do know that 22 of those who were retrenched in December at the Mount Thorley mine reside in his electorate. I suggest that it would be much more than 22 at the Hunter Valley No. 1 mine. Miners at Hunter Valley No. 1 are writing to the Maitland Mercury and saying, `Why won't my member represent me? Why won't he stand in the parliament and defend me like he is paid to do? Why won't he stand up to Rio Tinto? Why won't he oppose these disgraceful acts they are perpetrating upon us?' There were 22 at Mount Thorley and I suggest at least 40 people at Hunter Valley No. 1. They want to know why the member for Paterson won't even return their phone calls. Do you know what they are told? They are told—

talk.start.para: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. The member for Hunter is misrepresenting a position, and I will take that up later. They have never made calls that have not been returned.
—There is no point of order.

—They are told that neither Hunter Valley No. 1 nor Mount Thorley reside in the Paterson electorate. But so what? The people who work there are being attacked by a multinational company and their representative in the federal parliament will not stand and defend them. All we have heard today is a lot of waffle that will do nothing whatsoever to assist the constituents of the member for Paterson who are under attack by a multinational company with one objective in mind—to slash and abolish the trade union movement in this country. The member for Paterson does not care about the implications for his own constituents. He does not care how many families in his electorate will be without an income as a result.
—Order! The time allotted for this debate has expired. The debate is adjourned. The resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting.

—Following my briefing from the Treasury on the Multilateral Agreement on Investment last week, I read the latest draft of the MAI, which is available on the Australian government Treasury Internet site. Having read this latest document, my original concerns regarding the effects of the MAI on the people of Australia have been reinforced and remain as strong as ever.

speech.para: As it is not possible to download the text of the agreement from the Treasury Internet site onto a computer disk, it is very difficult and expensive to distribute the text of the treaty. Distributing the document is essential if the Australian people are to know what the government is negotiating and what that will mean for us all.

Also, the decision to examine the MAI through the Joint Standing Committee on Treaties is but a part of the cover-up and will not result in the concerns of ordinary Australians even getting a hearing, let alone being taken into account. Fifteen of the 16 members of the joint committee will be appointed by the government or the opposition. We all know the Labor Party started negotiations on the MAI in May 1995. Both the coalition and the Labor Party have demonstrated their commitment to signing the treaty.

Despite requests, I could not obtain a list of any Australian government exemptions to the treaty from the Treasury or any detailed information from the Parliamentary Library. My having to rely on the Internet for information on the MAI caused me to make contact with representatives of the Canadian parliament for help. These contacts, made in desperation, have been by fax, e-mail and phone, and began late last year. It is scandalous that a member of the federal parliament has to go to such lengths.

My accusation of secrecy remains, and I put to the Australian people the question: if the MAI is so good, why is this government even now still keeping all the important parts secret? This is not an issue of national security, so why is there so much secrecy? What is it that the government does not want the Australian people to know?

I will detail some of my specific concerns with the treaty. Equal treatment for multinationals may sound warm and fuzzy, but this will make it illegal for Australian levels of government to favour a local company over a foreign company. There are many good reasons why we should be able to discriminate in favour of Australian companies. For example, it will even be illegal for a local council to favour a local business over a foreign company for council work, or for deals to be negotiated with the understanding that money will stay in the community. Instead of the money and employment going into the local area, the work could be performed by foreign labour and the profits repatriated overseas, most likely untaxed.
The subject of multinationals importing labour may seem unlikely, but just listen to this paragraph from page 16 of the draft MAI:

No contracting party may deny entry and stay as provided for by this article, or authorisation to work as provided for by paragraph 1 (a) of this article, for reasons relating to labour market or other economic needs tests or numeric restrictions in national laws, regulations and procedures.

The treaty allows multinationals to bring in their own employees and their families, and we will have to give their spouses a work permit. Will these foreigners also get access to Medicare and other social security benefits? We have enough unemployment without multinationals bringing in their foreign workers.

As the Demtel man says, `But wait, there's more!' Under the MAI, no-one, not even the federal government, can attach conditions to foreigners who seek to establish themselves in Australia. For example, we will not be able to make a multinational use any Australian made components or domestic content. We will not be able to make a multinational establish a joint venture with any Australian company. We will not even be able to insist that multinationals employ any Australian people at all.

Within three years of signing this treaty, we will have to enter into negotiations to roll back and remove any current Australian laws that the multinationals do not like. Any exemptions the government proposes will likely be worthless in future and we will be forced to repeal them. The question of whether taxation constitutes a form of expropriation is not at all clear. As it stands, the Australian Taxation Office has already told us multinationals pay little or no tax now. If this agreement is signed in its current form, we may never be able to correct the pathetic situation of multinationals paying virtually no tax.

All levels of government in Australia are liable to be sued in the event of an infringement of multinationals' rights. Under the MAI it is compulsory for the government to enter into binding arbitration which will leave us, the Australia taxpayers, liable for damages and horrific fees. Under the protection from strife clause, the Australian people are also liable for any loss of profits resulting from a state of emergency. Just what exactly will that mean? As if this is not enough punishment for the innocent victims currently known as the Australian people, we will not be able to signal our wish to get out of the MAI for five years. After that, the treaty will continue in effect for another 15 years. The Australian people must be made aware that we will be bound by this draconian agreement for at least 20 years.

Australia is currently very good to foreign investors and many, including me, would argue that we are too good and give too much away. We have many resources, we have a well-educated work force and we have fairly good infrastructure. Multinationals get the benefits of our natural resources, infrastructure, stable society and educated population without contributing. More and more Australians are becoming aware of these facts and they are getting angry and becoming tired of being used. It is time to make multinationals and foreigners pay their share of tax.

It must be acknowledged that, whilst some foreign investment may be good, foreign control is not. It must also be understood the majority of foreign investment buys up existing profitable Australian companies and downsizes the work force. Much of what the government says about the benefits of foreign investment is simply a lie. Australia has relied far too heavily on foreign capital in the past, and we are now paying the price of high unemployment, a failing society and less ability to control our destiny. I maintain the MAI is largely being negotiated in secret, but it is not in the best interests of Australians and will benefit only the multinationals in their push for a single world economy. In its current form, the MAI will hand over vast powers to multinational companies which will plunder our country on their terms and then bill us for their time.

Rather than relying forever on foreign capital, only worsening the situation, One Nation policies will reindustrialise Australia and embark on programs of self-sufficiency. We will create jobs in diverse industries and lift our living standards. In short, One Nation will arrest the social decay that it would seem is almost a government sponsored plan. The day of the ballot box is coming.

talk.start.para: —I do not propose to use my time to respond too much to the previous speaker, the member for Oxley (Ms Hanson), but I want to make a couple of quick comments to her who, it seems to me, is indulging in her usual scare tactics. There is no secret plan at all. She herself admitted that she got the information off the Internet where the government put it. It is all out in the open. In terms of a treaties committee, the Joint Committee on Treaties already exists in this House and reports to this chamber. Nothing is concluded. If we do decide we want to sign such a treaty in some shape or form, it has of course got to go through a formal ratification process. What we have just heard is the usual farrago of scare tactics based on half-truths. I have to say that I am very disappointed that the member for Oxley continues to pedal this rubbish.

speech.para: Today I want to talk about a different subject. I want to talk about something that affects so many of our citizens in this country and is causing much angst and heartache, and that is the Child Support Agency. As you will be aware, Mr Deputy Speaker, something like 40 per cent of marriages in this country end up in divorce, many involving children. The subject of support for children is a very vexed and difficult one.

I want to talk about the ineffectiveness of the Child Support Agency in so many ways, especially in relation to the non-custodial parent who is self-employed and uses that as a ploy not to pay maintenance. I would like to read a letter that I received late last year from a constituent. This is the first opportunity I have had to bring this up in the chamber. I will edit it to the point where I protect some privacy, otherwise I will read it to the chamber because I think it is very instructive. This is from a lady who says:
As a concerned citizen I would like to point out an area of Taxation/child support laws that need urgent attention.

I am a sole parent with two children aged 11 and 9 years. My ex-husband is a self-employed . . . accountant "claiming" an annual income of $21,000. He has operated a business in . . . for approx. 3 years, buying a parcel of clients for $35,000 and setting up an office. He repaid the loan of $35,000 within a year. He is aged . . . and I am . . .
I am employed . . . as a state enrolled nurse working four days a week which includes Saturday between the hours of 9am and 3.30pm. My annual income is approx $20,000 including govt. payments.

I recently applied for a child support review for an increase in child support but I was denied. I previously applied for reviews only to have my ex-husband vary the amounts of his income, which he did several times.
For the review I supplied as my evidence the following—
1/ A four page letter outlining my circumstances and need for an increase.
2/ Copy of letter by investigative accountants which valued his business at $65,000 which of course my husband disputes.
3/ Copy of legal sworn Statement of Income signed by my ex-husband—

in which he admitted that prior to the divorce and the separation he had been earning $60,000 but, for tax purposes, had indulged in tax-splitting which made it look as if the wife had been getting $35,000. He admitted he had been earning $60,000. Suddenly and miraculously, he was only on $21,000 after the divorce. She goes on to say:
The advice of the child support office was to pursue this case through family court. This advice is laughable when I am already living on a low income/poverty line.
I am annoyed to think that this system seems to protect the self-employed person like my ex-husband. It seems to me that I now have no recourse to any relief.
I would also like to add that my mother is financing me as the property settlement is also in dispute, sadly my father passed away in October of this year.

My ex-husband "thumbs his nose" at the system because he can legally hide his true income by way of family or beneficiary trusts whilst the Australian taxpayer has to financially help his children by way of increased family payments.

My children and I still live in the marital home and my ex-husband was ordered by the courts to pay spousal maintenance to cover most of the mortgage payments which only came into force in February `97, a year before this date my parents kindly paid the mortgage.
There must be hundreds of other sole parents whose self-employed ex-spouses "hide" their true income which is legally protecting them and yet this system is allowed to go on without question.
I believe that income-splitting is viable within a marriage or partnership but why aren't the circumstances looked at in detail when these same relationships break down?
How on earth can justice be done when not one authority questions the system. This case shows that the system isn't working and I wonder if anyone "has a voice" to represent people like me?

Mr Deputy Speaker, you and I and other members of this place have heard about these sorts of cases on many hundreds of occasions. I have been in this parliament for some eight years and this would be one of a couple of hundred such cases that have come to me in my electorate. We are well aware that it happens on a regular basis to other members.

Doubtless, the officer from the Child Support Agency who reviewed this particular case acted in good faith and did his best. I am not having a go at the individual per se. My concern is with the system. Quite often, one hears how the non-custodial parent who has his own business, whatever the nature of that business may be, is able to so arrange his affairs that his taxable income is minimised. He can then use that as a way of avoiding paying child support because the Child Support Agency takes taxable income as the prime method of assessing any child support payments.

I acknowledge that it is sometimes dangerous for us in this place to highlight individual cases, but I am simply using this case to give an example of how this is happening in an overwhelming number of situations. In recent times, we have heard a lot about non-custodial parents—and they are usually, although not exclusively, fathers—and the difficulties they face; how they often have to pay a lot of money to support their children and so do not have enough money to rebuild their lives and so on and so forth. There is no doubt that that happens on many occasions.

Unfortunately, that only tends to happen when the non-custodial parent, the father, is in employment. If he is in employment, when the mother, who is the custodial parent in most cases, applies for maintenance then those wages can be garnisheed—in other words, the money is taken out of his pay and paid over directly. However, in the case where the non-custodial parent—and it can be a female as well as a male—is self-employed, he can arrange matters under the tax system to minimise the amount of pay, and so we cannot garnishee his income.

My concern is that, although there have been a number of written reviews—a parliamentary report, and this House passed amendments to the Child Support Agency and family law legislation last year and other changes are to be introduced in the fairly near future—my concern is that the system is still not working in practice. For example, the written assessment from the review officer in this case, which I do not have time to read out, says that they do not only rely on tax information.

However, in my experience, with the many cases that I have dealt with, if you put forward other information to the Child Support Agency, it almost never takes account of that; it only ever takes account of the taxable income. In the judgment in this case, the Child Support Agency complained that the information was supplied by the wife and that it could not take only her word. However, in this case, for example, the Child Support Agency was supplied with a legal document in which the former husband admitted the amount of money that he had been earning—but that was set aside.
