speech.para: Last Friday morning we held a rally at Belmont in support of the retention of the Belmont Medicare office in my electorate. The rally was well attended. What was clear from many people who attended and observed the rally was the very strong opposition to this government's dismantling of Medicare. People at the rally were most vocal in their support of the Belmont Medicare office in particular and Medicare in general. People do not believe the promise of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) to support Medicare. Australians are becoming aware that, whilst proclaiming support for Medicare, the government is busily, brutally and irresponsibly closing down 43 Medicare offices across Australia. That assault on Medicare means that hundreds of thousands of retirees, young families and sick people will not be able to get immediate cash refunds after they have paid their doctor's bill.

The government's war with the medical profession is causing fewer and fewer doctors to bulk-bill. In my electorate thousands of my constituents need immediate cash refunds of their payment for doctors to enable them to purchase their prescribed pharmaceuticals and in some cases their groceries and their foodstuffs for the evening and the next day. As a result of this government's actions, increasing numbers of my constituents, retirees and young families, have to pay their doctor's bill at the time of consultation or often before the consultation takes place.

Take the case of a young family with below average weekly earnings. The doctor's bill can be anywhere between $30 and $50, which they have to outlay in cash. Then again as a result of this government's actions their pharmaceuticals are $20 per script. So if they have two scripts and a visit to the doctor, they could be outlaying anywhere from $70 to over $100. Many families just do not have a spare $100 to outlay in that fashion.

So the closure of Medicare offices is harsh, deliberate and hurtful to those families. We need to understand this is the deliberate policy of this government. People understand that. It is absolutely clear that the government is determined to dismantle Medicare. That is evidenced by the Prime Minister's statement on the Sunday program of 1 March. When asked by Laurie Oakes, `So you guarantee that, if you win the election, for the next three years Medicare will remain unchanged?' the Prime Minister responded, `Well, the essentials of Medicare will remain unchanged, of course they will, of course they will.'

We know that is code for the end of Medicare because this is the same man who as Treasurer promised to maintain Medibank and then spent seven years dismantling Medibank. People know that and they do not trust him. This is the same former Treasurer who gave us the $27 billion deficit, the highest cash interest rates in history, double digit inflation, the highest rate of inflation since World War II with the exception of the Korean War, and double digit unemployment. And with Prime Minister Fraser he presided over the dismantling of the original Medibank after having promised to maintain it.

My constituents do not believe his words. They know his code language. They do not trust this government and they want the Belmont Medicare office retained. I spoke to the minister again last week, I have mentioned it to him this evening and I am speaking here. Again I appeal to the minister on behalf of my thousands of constituents who need that immediate cash payment service. Bear this in mind: you dismantle Medicare at your peril. The people do not trust you. They are suspicious of this government. They know this Prime Minister's role as Treasurer.

We want the Medicare office at Belmont retained for the benefit of those young families, those retirees and those people who cannot afford to outlay $90 to $110 to pay the doctor and to pay for their pharmaceuticals and then wait to get their money back. So this attack by the government is properly recognised by the people in my electorate. They understand. They do not trust this government. You interfere with Medicare, as you are doing, at your peril. (Time expired)

—I would like tonight to pay tribute to the Reverend Arthur Menkens, who died in a road accident near Brandon in February of this year. Reverend Menkens was born in Ayr in April 1918, the eighth of nine children. Reverend Menkens's life spanned farming, the priesthood and a rich community service to the people of Dawson.

speech.para: His family moved to a sugar farm at Home Hill when he was seven. They worked to build it up, successfully fending off foreclosure during the Depression. `We lived off our own grown foods and learned the lesson waste not, want not,' he said. He attended Osborne School and Ayr High School before starting work as a laboratory assistant at Kalamia mill near Ayr in 1933. Over the next four years, Arthur attended the Central Technical College in Brisbane, now QUT, and gained a diploma in sugar chemistry. During the slack seasons, he worked as a cane tester at the former Cattle Creek mill at Finch Hatton and Maryborough mill. In 1937 he returned to the Burdekin as shift chemist at Kalamia. In 1939 he worked in New Zealand as a builder's labourer, wharfie and dairy hand.

The Depression and wars had a big impact on the lives of Arthur's generation, and he found himself back home helping his parents keep the farm going. He married Gwynneth Mann, a farmer's daughter, from Home Hill in 1942. They had the following children: Ray, and daughters Marilyn (Stokes), Jennifer (Crocker), Kathryn (Lyons) and Bronwyn Menkens, who were born on the dairy farm and added to the output of the farm with their energetic assistance.

In 1950 Arthur and Gwynn won the Royal National Show's dairy competition for the zone extending from Rockhampton to Townsville. Arthur's involvement in the community ranged across school, church, Masonic, farming and political interests. He also spent a great deal of time and research seeking life's basic truths. He remained for many years rather sceptical of the relevance of the conventional churches. But the Masonic concept of the brotherhood of man under the fatherhood of God gave him a new and positive direction in his search. He told me how he had had a vision of Christ, and it was this that encouraged him to study at St Francis Anglican Theological College in 1968.

At the age of 50 years, his career changed from being a farmer to having a radically new life as an Anglican minister. This brought him tremendous challenges with personal and spiritual demands, which channelled his fighting spirit. His wife Gwynn was always his anchor and support. They worked in parishes in Townsville, Gordonvale, Proserpine and Home Hill, followed by locums in both north and south Queensland. In 1989 they spent two months at Holy Trinity Parish in Mackay. They retired in 1983, and Arthur and Gwynn continued their very active work in the church and their interest in political and community affairs.

It is not often that late in life one is able to be an author. Only last year Arthur realised his long cherished dream of publishing his own book on theology entitled God's Deal. It dealt with the eternal question of why in a God loving earth there is still disease, famine and despair. I do not know whether Arthur had the right answer, but he certainly has challenged all of us in his book.

Arthur and Gwynn spent eight happy years back on their farm in Home Hill, living next door to their son and daughter-in-law. This allowed them to live next door to three of their growing grandchildren: Penny, Emily and Anna. It is significant that on the weekend that Arthur was killed he was doing something he greatly enjoyed—travelling to Townsville to share in the investiture of new priests for the Anglican Church there. As it was said at Arthur's funeral, while his earthly life had closed, his spiritual journey with Christ was continuing. I offer my condolences to his wife Gwynn and his children.

talk.start.para: —Recently, along with thousands of other Geelong residents, I attended Geelong's annual Pako Festa—one of Australia's premier multicultural events. The festival com menced with the opening of the Chinese costume exhibition at the Geelong West town hall on 21 February, with one of the main highlights of the week's activities held on Saturday the 28th, when 31 ethnic groups in Geelong participated in the annual Pako Festa carnival parade.

speech.para: The Pako Festa is a unique multicultural festival, and I pay tribute to all those people from Geelong's ethnic community who worked tirelessly to stage this extremely important event. In particular, I pay tribute to Mr George Ballas, chairman of the organising committee, and all other members of the organising committee who gave freely of their time to organise such a spectacular multicultural event. Mr Jordan Mavros, of the Migrant Resource Centre, also served on that committee. Councillor Margaret Lewis, wearing two hats, representing the City of Greater Geelong and the Geelong West Traders Association, has been a strong supporter down through the years for the Festa.

I also pay tribute to Ms Anna Vrantsis, the artistic and marketing director of the festival, on whose shoulders fell the onerous task of securing sponsorships and developing and coordinating the festival's artistic program; Mr Frank O'Neil, the administrator; and the staff of Geelong's Migrant Resource Centre who supported the organising committee on the day to ensure the smooth running of the festival. The Geelong community owes a great debt to the visionaries of the Geelong Ethnic Communities Council, the Geelong West Traders Association and the old Geelong West Council, which initiated the Pako Festa in 1983.

Geelong is an ethnically diverse community. The Pako Festa has been an important vehicle down through the years for both large and small ethnic communities in Geelong to showcase their cultures. It has been a powerful force for bringing all citizens of Geelong together in a spirit of true community at a time when international events and civic strife overseas have had the potential to seriously divide Geelong's ethnic communities. The Festa now represents a major source of fundraising for many ethnic groups, enabling their associations to continue to assist their mem bers. It is indeed a powerful vehicle for the promotion and sustenance of diverse cultures in our local community.

The Pako Festa has had an interesting history. It commenced in 1983 as a one-day festival and has grown to where today the festival runs for a week and involves a range of cultural activities which include exhibitions, concerts, street theatre, a song fest, food fairs and, of course, the now famous Pako Festa parade.

This year some 31 ethnic groups and an estimated 2,300 participants contributed to the Pako Festa's success. Of particular significance was the active involvement of Geelong's Wathaurong Aboriginal Community and Education Centre in the Festa for the first time. The Geelong community was both excited and honoured by their participation.

I congratulate the City of Greater Geelong for its financial involvement in the Pako Festa and encourage the city to remain active in its financial and logistical support for the event. To other sponsors such as Rohm and Haas, Sunicrust Bakeries, Arts Victoria, the Transport Accident Commission, Vic-Health, Barwon Water, Festivals Australia and the Geelong West Traders Association, thanks for your support.

It is very important that the Pako Festa continue and be developed further as an important Festa in Geelong. The Geelong Migrant Resource Centre, through its multicultural arts officer, has played a pivotal role in organising the Festa. It is therefore regrettable that the multicultural arts officer position, which up until recently received full funding, has been reduced by half. I would ask the Australia Council to restore funding for this position to secure the continuance of the festival.
